title: Private Pilot License (PPL) Training
subtitle: ISAE-SUPAERO Air Operations Centre
description:
Flying has always been one of my biggest motivations for studying aerospace engineering. In 2024, I began my Private Pilot License (PPL) training at the ISAE-SUPAERO Air Operations Centre, a selective program that offers students the chance to gain real flight experience while studying.

Through this formation, I'm learning not only to fly an aircraft but also to understand it from an operational point of view — how every system interacts, how decisions are made in dynamic environments, and how teamwork and communication become essential in the cockpit.

This experience has changed the way I see engineering: it connects the theory of systems and avionics I study in class with the tangible feeling of flight. Every lesson in the air reinforces my passion for aerospace and my wish to design systems that pilots can trust and enjoy flying.

title: Sparrow Rocket Project
subtitle: SUPAERO Space Section x CNES
description:
I joined the Sparrow project, a student-led initiative within the ISAE-SUPAERO Space Section, carried out in collaboration with CNES as part of a guided rocketry program. Our goal was to design and build a fully functional model rocket, from concept to launch.

The rocket structure combined a PVC tube fuselage, 3D-printed fairing and internal components, and laser-cut ailerons, all adapted to its weight, length, and mass distribution for improved flight stability. The avionics system was based on a Raspberry Pi Pico controller with a Raspberry Rocket module, powered by a compact battery and servo mechanism to deploy the parachute mid-flight.

My main contributions focused on the design and manufacturing of 3D-printed components in CATIA, assisting with the flight control code, and participating in the final assembly and system integration.

This project gave me a tangible sense of how mechanical, electronic, and software aspects merge into a working system — and the satisfaction of seeing something we designed actually take off. However, as you can see in the photos, the landing was not really smooth...
